Spring 2015 Schedule    | German | NYU                                                                                                                                                     Back to Previous Page         Spring 2015 Schedule      Spring  2015 Schedule   GERM-UA114         T, R 9:30-10:45   Advanced Composition – The German  Novella: Realism’s X-Files  Chadwick Smith  Beginning with Goethe’s definition of the novella as the genre in which “the  unheard-of occurs,” the novella has played a unique role in German Literature.  This course introduces students to the genre through readings of representative  novellas, demonstrating how the genre is often the home of supernatural events  such as demonic possession or a plague of spiders that materialize from  nowhere. Given that the novella is also the genre most closely associated with  literary realism, we will focus mainly on the 19th century and the relation  between the novella’s strange status as bearer of the unexplainable and the era  of realism’s taxonomic project of assembling and depicting data about the world  in an effort to produce coherence. This course is designed to provide advanced  students of German an opportunity to expand both their reading knowledge of  German and, through sustained projects) their writing skills in the language.     *This course will be  conducted in German.        GERM-UA152  M,  W 9:30 – 10:45  Introduction  to German Literature    Christiane  Frey  Required for the German major. Introduces students to representative authors  and exemplary works of German literature from the 18th to the 21st century.  Students learn about the basic conventions of literature and literary  interpretation, as well as strategies for the effective reading and discussion  of poetry, prose, and drama. Guided writing assignments focus on developing the  language skills necessary for effective written analysis and interpretation of  literary texts in German.  *This course will be  conducted in German.         GERM-UA244       (COLIT-UA244/EURO-UA292/HIST-UA  552 )  M, W 11:00 – 12:15   German Intellectual Tradition - The Age of Angst : German and  Austrian Intellectual History, 1890-1938   Alys George  This course explores the profound sense of crisis, uncertainty, and anxiety  that pervaded German and Austrian experience in the late nineteenth and early  twentieth centuries. The era’s radical changes—among them the traumas of war,  rapid industrialization and urbanization, shifting gender roles, and the  political and economic instability of the interwar years—seemed to shake the  very bedrock upon which society had been built. The intellectual responses to  this pervasive sense of upheaval and angst , as well as  the challenges and changes themselves, form the focus of this course, as we  explore the relationship between modernity and crisis in early  twentieth-century Germany and Austria. Readings will include Nietzsche, Freud,  Simmel, Weber, Kracauer, Benjamin, and Heidegger. Taught in English.  GERM-UA249   (COLIT-UA249) T, R 2:00  – 3:15  Introduction to  Theory – German Media Theory: From Aesthetics to Cultural Techniques    Chadwick Smith  This course presents a survey of the German strain of media theory from the  perspective of the persistent interchanges and parallels between it and social  thought and forms. We will follow a trajectory that can be roughly outlined by  four movements: 1) Media theory’s ancestors in classical philosophy; 2) The  boom in aesthetic theory that took place in 18th-century German philosophy, one  still based in a humanistic understanding of the world; 3) late 20th-century  discussions of discourse networks and systems theory, which attempt to  de-center the human subject in favor of an understanding of the technical  forces that drive history; and 4) the contemporary understanding of the  intertwined nature of technical media and culture proposed in the school of  “cultural techniques.” Thus this course additionally addresses the ways in  which Media Studies provides a template for understanding the ethical, legal,  and social position of human subject in the “digital” and technologically  mediated world. Taught in English.  GERM-UA377         M,  W 2:00 – 3:15   Modern  German Drama: Theaters of War (Goethe to Brecht)  Christiane  Frey    When  military strategists speak of a “theater of operations,” or when the  nineteenth-century war theorist Carl von Clausewitz coins the term “theater of  war,” they are not just using an empty metaphor: we think of war as a kind of  drama played out within a bounded area over a certain period of time. It’s thus  no accident that authors have turned to drama as a genre on which to reflect on  war – its dynamics, its causes, its seeming inevitability, its consequences,  its mediality. In this course, we will explore how theater stages war and  terror, beginning with plays written shortly before or after the French  Revolution – whose “reign of terror” gave us our concept of “terrorism” – to 20th-century  modernist and experimental dramas of war. We will also explore various theoretical  approaches to war and terror. Plays by Goethe, Kleist, Büchner, Brecht, Peter  Weiss, Heiner Müller; theoretical writings by Clausewitz, Carl Schmitt, Freud,  Paul Virilio, and Friedrich Kittler. Requirements: oral presentation, take home  exam, three short papers.  *This course will be  conducted in German.
